title: 109_s2384
content: The Act titled "Gulf Coast Protection and Restoration Act of 2006" also addresses offshore oil and gas leasing in the 181 area of the Gulf of Mexico. The "181 Area" and "Military Mission Line" are defined in this section by the Secretary of the Interior. The Secretary is required to offer the 181 Area for oil and gas leasing within one year of the Act's enactment, excluding certain areas. The 181 Area shall be offered for oil and gas leasing, excluding areas east of the Military Mission Line and within 100 miles of the Florida coastline. The revenues from leasing in this area will be disposed of as defined in the subsection. The term "producing State" refers to a state with a coastal boundary on the Gulf of Mexico within 200 nautical miles of a leased tract in the 181 Area, excluding certain states. "Qualified outer Continental Shelf revenues" is defined as specified revenues from the outer Continental Shelf. The term "qualified outer Continental Shelf revenues" is defined in section 31(a) of the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act. The Secretary is required to disburse 50% of these revenues to producing States and coastal political subdivisions from leases in the 181 Area without needing further appropriation. The allocation of funds is done in accordance with section 31(b) of the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act. Under section 31(b) of the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act, funds disbursed to producing States and coastal political subdivisions must be used in accordance with applicable laws for specified purposes outlined in section 31(d)(1) of the Act. Under the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act, funds must be used for onshore infrastructure projects, public service needs, hazard mitigation, energy production, conservation, and cost-sharing for authorized projects. Producing States and coastal political subdivisions must adhere to the Coastal Impact Assistance Plan when using these funds. The Governor of a producing State must submit an amendment to the coastal impact assistance plan if funds are used in a manner different from what is specified. Limitations on revenue generated from a leased tract in the 181 Area do not apply to certain sections of the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act.
